title: Wednesday, 6th November 2019
bodyHTML:
VV75 morning
11:05 am
BE11:06am

Morning! Exciting news.

nightingale20201 Morning all
Soundbuy Morning
Blank canvas Tick Tock - not many days left
BE11:06am

Steve Bannon, the mastermind of Donald Trump's presidential campaign, hopes to assemble a consortium that would turn FT Alphaville's Markets Live blog into the global voice of Trumpian populism, according to sources close to things.

BE11:06am

"It's one of the great untapped properties," said Bannon, who co-founded Breitbart News, the US platform that has been accused of encouraging racism and white supremacy, in an unrelated story in the Sunday Times.
Bannon might plausibly believe that the traditionally UK equities-focused Markets Live, under new management, can become an international brand promoting populist nationalism. Or perhaps he doesn't. We don't know. We haven't asked him.
Bannon has claimed some sections of the UK media moved to the right during the Brexit era for fear of competition from a UK edition of Breitbart, but had not moved far enough. He believes British rightwingers need to be rescued from Tory "grandees" reluctant to associate themselves with Trump. "It's all that Oxford-Cambridge stuff," he was quoted as saying.
Less clear is whether Bannon can come up with the nine-figure asking price. "Not sure they really want to sell, so may be [a] total waste of time," he added in the unrelated Sunday Times story.
Bruce Elder, an intern at FT Alphaville, declined to comment.

nightingale20201 MKS please, many thanks Bryce..
Raver morning
Plato the Cook Hola
Grouchmonkey Bonjour

Let's get through the first thing first.

Marks and Spencer Group PLC (MKS:LSE): Last: 186.40, up 4.05 (+2.22%), High: 196.70, Low: 185.20, Volume: 5.81m
A. M. @TomD MLdammerung?
nightingale20201 @Tom ....fyi, BE won't be running the last act (rite) on Friday..
BE11:12am

Numbers are bad but they were known to be.

BE11:12am

Here's Barclays.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Against a set of reduced expectations, this seems to us like a reasonable outcome for M&S. As hoped, Food seems to be on an improving trend. Clothing & Home clearly remains problematic, but the gross margin guidance cut reflects pain taken in 1H rather than expected in 2H. There seems to be good progress on cost, which means the impact of weak Clothing sales is less than one might have expected. Moreover, there are some reasons for optimism about recent sales trends in this division.

BE11:12am

Key numbers (Pre-IFRS 16):

· 1H reported Food LFL: +0.9% (vs Barclays +0.4%, consensus +0.3%), including positive calendar impact of +0.9% (+1.8% in 1Q).

· 1H Food gross margin: fell by -20bps to 31%% (vs Barclays -5bps, guidance of +/- 25bps for FY19/20 overall).

· 1H Clothing & Home reported LFL: -5.5% (vs Barclays -5.6%, consensus -4.3%).

· 1H gross margin for Clothing & Home: fell by -105bps to 57.1% (vs Barclays -20bps, guidance of +/- 25bps for FY19/20 overall).

· The weak 1H gross margin was driven partly by bringing forward certain promotional activities from 2H into 1H. M&S saw (in admittedly a stronger market) October full price and planned promotional sales rise by +2.7%.

· UK operating costs fell by 3.3% in 1H – M&S seems to be making good progress against its cost targets and expects to be 80% of the way through its three-year £350m cost saving plan by the end of 19/20.

· 1H underlying PBT was £176.5m POST IFRS 16 – our forecast was £169m and consensus was £174m both pre IFRS 16 and the IFRS 16 impact was c£7m – therefore on a like-for-like basis PBT was c5% ahead of consensus.

· Net debt excluding lease liability: £1.59bn (vs Barclays at £1.52bn) and pension surplus was £991.2mn (£914.3mn at end of FY18/19).

· 1H dividend: down by 40% as guided to 3.9p (vs Barclays 3.9p, consensus of 4.0p).

BE11:13am

So, sales remain in a mire but costs are coming out.

Tom Dalgleish Will old ML’s still be visible?
Viking1 Another warning from ISS Dk
11:13 am
BE11:13am

Which is ....... good? I guess? Reconfiguring the cost base for sales going into retrenchment permanently?

BE11:13am

hanges in guidance:

· UK opex now expected to fall by 1-2% (vs 0-1% fall previously).

· Clothing & Home net space impact now expected to be c-2ppts (vs -3ppts previously).

· Food net space impact now expected to be flat (vs c-1ppt previously).

· These space changes are due to timing rather than any change in the extent of the closure plan.

· Capex of £300-350m (vs £350-400m previously).

· Clothing & Home gross margin now expected to fall 25-75bps (vs +- 25bps previously).

· No change to Food GM guidance of +-25bps. Expect some improvement in conditions in 2H, but market remains challenging.

· Company is not expecting to see pre IFRS 16 PBT consensus for FY19 to change materially (currently quoted at £474m).

Mr Grumpy You guys happy to just let ML die? AV is next on the list. How much would you be prepared to pay a month for both?
BE11:13am

Cheap though!

11:13 am
BE11:13am

M&S trades on a FY21E PE of 8.9x the sector average of 13.8x (inc Sainsbury on 10.4x and Morrison on 14.5x).

BE11:14am

And Shore.

BE11:14am

Looking at the guidance, gross margins in C&H are guided lower but unchanged in Food whilst operating cost reduction is expected to be greater than previously indicated. All in all, we stay with our present FY2020 PTP & EPS expectations (pre-IFRS), noting much potential volatility ahead (e.g. UK General Election) and a fundamental requirement for C&H trading momentum to improve on a more sustained basis than a better October, albeit is very welcome. A sub-5 times (x) EV/EBITDA ratio, sub-10x PER, 5%+ DPS yield and double-digit medium-term FCF yield should provide substantial downside support for the shares to us, but trading progress in both operating camps with profit upgrades is necessary for the stock to positively take-off.

Soundbuy PM and NH Friday............I'll have to get some beers in......hopefully BE will 'pop' in

BE11:16am

IS that enough? Yes, no? Here's Investec anyway.

BE11:16am

A disappointing 1H
 While 1H20 results have come in in-line with expectations, forecasts were downgraded in advance. We view this as another
disappointing performance, particularly in Clothing & Home. M&S is still struggling to stabilise the business and running hard
to stand still. Management has changed its clothing buying approach/ranges for 2H and expects performance to improve as
a result. Food performance was better than expected, but the business continues to struggle to grow LFL sales.
 We stick with our view that the £350m of targeted cost savings will have to be reinvested into the business and this strategy
is one of profit stabilisation at best. We believe the valuation (CY20E PE 10x) is not compelling enough for little/no medium
term growth with little improvement in newsflow likely over the next 12 months. Sell reiterated.
Clothing & Home disappointing, with Food slightly better
 Reported underlying 1H20 PBT £176.5m (-17.1%) compares to our forecast of £172m pre IFRS 16. EPS were 7.1p (-24.5%)
and DPS 3.9p (-40%)
 This was driven by a weak sales performance in Clothing & Home (total sales down 7.8% impacted by store closures with
LFL down 5.5%) and gross margin was down 105bps (buying margin down 50bps and higher discounts cost 50bps).
Performance was impacted by the shape of first half buy and supply chain issues.
 Food performance was solid, with revenues up 1.2% and LFL +0.9%, driven by volume. Gross margin down 20bps.
 FY20 Guidance has changed – UK Food sales contribution from space flat (prev -1%) with gross margin -25bps to +25bps
(unchanged). Clothing & Home sales contribution from space down 2% (prev -3%) with gross margin -25bps to -75bps (prev
-25bps to +25bps); UK operating costs down 1-2% (prev c.0-1%)
 The consensus expectation for FY20 PBT of £474m (range £440m- £506m) is unlikely to change materially in our view.

YourGrannyOnBongos @Soundbuy - I will now be dealing with a plumber (as in, letting him in and keeping an eye on him, not 'dealing with' him in the mafia sense) during the last ever ML, not sure he'd have been willing to reschedule based on me having a pre-existing commitment to watch some people type things

The M1 Cement stake sale now makes sense of the shareholder
announcement on October 21st and the share price weakness
since then. That announcement split the ABICAD stake (c.18.35%
of Breedon) into an ABICAD-Mittal family stake of 9.8% and a M1
Cement stake of 8.55%. M1 Cement now appears to have sold its
entire position in the company at c.59p. Breedon Group will
update on trading on November 20th. With UK construction
activity softer in September and October, we have modestly
reduced our earnings estimates for the stock.

BE11:20am

Breedon will provide an update on Q3 trading on Wednesday November 20th. A spate of disappointing peer and economic updates suggests that UK trading has likely proved difficult in September and October and, as such, we have slightly lowered estimates for 2019. We now expect the group to report FY19 underlying EBIT of £115.7m, down from £117.1m previously. For 2020, we now assume
underlying EBIT of £121.4m, some 2.3% below our previous estimate. While
trading may prove volatile through the rest of the year, we still expect the group to deliver to plan on debt reduction. We assume net debt (including the impact of IFRS16) falls to £295.5m by year-end, implying net debt/EBITDA of just 1.7x.

BE11:32am

Our own views are: 1) We don’t expect any deal to complete prior to the known outcome of the FCA & PRA regulatory investigation as a buyer / bedfellow will not want to take the risk of exposing itself to material potential litigation claims. 2) We believe that the Board is most likely pushing for a potential tie-up with a third party, which could potentially involve MTRO acquiring higher-yielding assets (thereby, denoting NIM and RoTE enhancement) as well as a concurrent sale of mainstream residential mortgage assets (as well as the assets that were the subject of the RWA misstatements) to third parties like mainstream banks. To be clear, we doubt that the Board is engaging with the large cap banks for the purposes of a desired solution though we suspect conversations will be had with this lot in the context of contingency planning. Instead, we would see the likes of Chetwood Financial (Elliott) or Kensington (Northview; ultimately Blackstone) as far better examples of the kind of candidates that the Board has in mind. This will not come as news to anyone who has been reading our published research reports. However, MTRO will be at the mercy of any third party, and while we believe there is residual value in the equity, we feel that the market has become overexcited – particularly given we don’t know what the outcome of the regulatory investigation is yet.

BE11:33am

All of which seems sensible.

We have a clear plan to do this and are working to make material progress over the next six months. We continue to consider all options to put us in the best position to deal with both our short and medium term liquidity requirements as we approach our next material debt maturity in early 2021. These options include disposing of assets, where we are in the advanced stages of selling two of our Spanish assets, through to raising equity, which is also likely to form part of the solution.

BE11:45am

Intu released its 19Q3 trading statement this morning which once more
struck a cautionary tone suggesting CVAs were again slightly worse than
expected. The company also continues to hint more and more that an
equity raise may be needed to solve this problem which is also our base
case. In reality the company will struggle to execute the Trafford Centre
refinancing without having first sorted out the balance sheet. But in order
to re-capitalise the company, it would first need to convince investors that
the worst of the CVA processes are over, which clearly they are not as yet.
Therefore the company is likely to have to bide its time through what could be a difficult Christmas trading period, and perhaps all the way until 20H1
numbers. At that point the deadline for the Trafford Centre refinancing will be getting closer to within a year of its deadline (Oct 2021), and hence a recapitalisation of the company will become more immanent. The question at that point becomes how much equity will be needed? To which the answer probably lies between £1-2bn depending on whether its done with new
investors or existing ones. Either way, it will be highly dilutive.

BE11:56am

We believe this deal will make Virgin Media a more credible player in convergence, with 5G services, and no doubt better network economics (be it absolute price or inflation protection), and so see potentially increased retail competition (Virgin has recently increased its marketing of convergent tariffs). In the Enterprise market (where BT has c50% market share, and currently declining c5-10%/year) we see greater competitive risk as Vodafone is set to average into the market with better economics. As a separate aside, this deal does highlight the risks of EU Telcos – High fixed cost businesses with low ROCE, but low marginal cost can result in such deals. As a result, we would not expect Vodafone to extrapolate this deal to other markets where it could risk high value Retail revenues (such as Germany).

The UK business is being dragged out to sea and scuttled while the international side gets to keep the brand etc.

BE12:04pm

Numis, an advisor, can talk us through the detail.

BE12:04pm

UK retail: Despite management efforts, it became apparent the business was not able
to recover to a level of structural profitability nor be sufficiently attractive to a third-party
partner to operate on an arms-length basis. The administrator is expected to oversee
the closure of all retail operations and support areas.
● Franchise: The Group has transferred in the Mothercare brand, its trademarks and
associated intellectual property, the commercial agreements relating to international
franchise operations, and the Group’s pension scheme deficit. From here the Group
will focus on global product design, sourcing and marketing, to support its franchise
partners in over 1,000 stores across 40 territories. From here, management intends to
seek to grow the franchise partner base. Discussions are also ongoing with a number
of parties to maintain a brand presence in the UK.
● Management Guidance: The restructuring is expected to result in (i) the elimination
of c.£30m of UK retail operating losses, (ii) FY20 cash exceptional costs of c.£5m, (iii)
a pro-forma operating profit base of £10-15m, and (iv) a cash generative business.
● Financing: Senior debt facilities totaling £24m are expected to be repaid through
the stock liquidation process. The company expects to be bank debt free by the
year end. An equity placing to existing shareholders has raised £3.2m (at 10p per
share). An agreement in principle has been reached with two existing investors on the
terms for the issuance of £5.5m of convertible unsecured loan notes. An underwriting
commitment has been agreed for a potential further equity placing of up to £25m, with
the Board assessing the need for this in light of the progress of the restructuring and
administration process. The Group has been provided with a term sheet for a new
£15m secured term loan facility that is being reviewed. A debtor-backed facility of up to
US$10m remains available. Mothercare pension trustees have agreed to a reduction
in planned contributions over the next 18 months.

FY20 PBT estimates are unchanged but we will use the
H1 results on 10 Dec to update the PBT composition and fully reflect the revised
financing. Our initial analysis of the direct financial impact of the administration and
refinancing, on a pro-forma basis, suggests the revamped MTC, unencumbered by
the UK business’s c£30m losses, can generate EBITDA margins in excess of 10% in
FY21 on unheroic assumptions. Assuming no y/y revenue growth, we see MTC
capable of making c£160m in revenues generating c£20m of EBITDA which, given
MTC’s move to an asset-light model and therefore little attendant depreciation, is
supportive of MTC’s conservatively framed assessment that it can make £10-15m of
EBIT. This analysis does not take into account the strong probability that a potential
UK franchise partner can be found (here the news is encouraging), nor the possibility
for further important operating cost reductions. Beyond FY21, we see revenue upside
potential from MTC adding new franchise partners in currently unserved countries.
